page.title: 16HANG GLIDING
page.content: The sudden rise of the escarpment from the Tees river plain that forms the Northern edge of the North Yorks Moors makes a site that is eminently suitable for hang gliding. Any wind from Northern points of the compass results in a dramatic up-draught which is used to carry hang gliders high above the edge. They can then circle and fly for long periods before landing in almost the same place as they took off. Warm clothes are essential for hang gliding, as is reasonable visibility. We do not know of any fatal accidents that have taken place in this area. There have been complaints that hang gliders can startle sheep carrying lambs and cause them to abort. Recently, stretches of road have been fenced in order to prevent parking on them by those wanting access to Carlton Bank.
